blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Testing Data

lede.lede: At least three different federal agencies share testing data for SARS-CoV-2 in at least four different places. blog_post.title: Federal Testing Data’s Last Mile

lede.lede: Federal testing data is already more standardized and more detailed than the data we compile from states can ever be. But in some jurisdictions, state-provided data still provides a more comprehensive picture of testing volume. The federal government should address lingering quality problems so its data can become the national standard.

blog_post.title: Silent Data Mismatches Are Compromising Key COVID-19 Indicators

blog_post.title: Better COVID-19 Data Is Coming By August 1—But Will the Public See It?

lede.lede: Starting in August, new federal rules will require testing labs to report better data on the spread of COVID-19 in the United States. What happens to this new information is up to state and local officials. Journalists, open-data advocates, and members of the public can help us hold governments accountable for collecting and publishing this urgently needed data.

blog_post.title: All Eyes on Hospitalizations: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Dec 30

blog_post.title: How We Source Our Data and Why It Matters

lede.lede: States provide COVID-19 data in a variety of sources and formats. To ensure our data is as accurate and consistent as possible, we spend a lot of time looking at these sources to make sure that we’re capturing the most data possible for each state, while maintaining high standards of data quality and integrity. Today, we’re publicly releasing a detailed set of notes on the sources of all our data points.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Counting COVID-19 Tests: How States Do It, How We Do It, and What’s Changing

lede.lede: Many states have moved toward greater transparency about their test data reporting methods, and we’re making changes to better represent what they publish. We’re also introducing a “new” way some states are counting tests—one we think all states and territories would be wise to embrace.

blog_post.title: Test Types 101: The Pros and Cons of Different Approaches

lede.lede: Once limited to molecular tests, the United States now has other testing methods available. Their efficacy depends on multiple factors, including how far the person tested is in their infection and how high the test positivity is where they live.

blog_post.title: Holiday Reporting Lags Interrupt Positive Trends: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 17

lede.lede: Though cases are rising in parts of the Midwest, hospitalizations in the West and South continued trending downward. The Labor Day holiday impacted data reporting lag times both this week and last, obscuring what had been positive trends in September.

blog_post.title: Cases Stop Dropping and the Midwest Heats Up: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 3

lede.lede: After five straight weeks of sharp declines in new cases of COVID-19 in the United States, we’ve leveled off again. Reported tests are up about 5 percent, but are actually dropping in the Midwest, where three states—Iowa, North Dakota, and South Dakota—are driving an uptick in new cases. This week we also launched a new dataset that looks closely at the toll of COVID-19 in nursing homes and other long-term care facilities.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Conor Kelly is the director of data analytics at Hanover Research.
Judith Oppenheim works on Texas City Data and state outreach at The COVID Tracking Project.
Pat Kelly is a technology executive and entrepreneur based in Austin, Texas, and works on The COVID Racial Data Tracker and The Long-Term Care COVID Tracker at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Something Is Wrong with Testing Data in the Great State of Texas

lede.lede: According to the official state numbers, COVID-19 testing has dropped dramatically in August. However, county-level statistics show the opposite story. What’s going on?

blog_post.title: Tests, Cases, and Hospitalizations Keep Dropping: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Aug 13

lede.lede: Testing continues to fall, especially in the South, one of the areas where the country needs it the most. Cases, too, are falling, which remains hard to interpret, given the testing decline—but fewer people are now in the hospital with COVID-19 than last week. This is the second week in a row that hospitalizations seem to have dropped, which suggests that infections may be declining independently of testing reductions.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Júlia Ledur is a visual journalist and illustrator who leads the visualization team at The COVID Tracking Project. She is a former graphics reporter at Reuters.
Emma Rubin is a recent college graduate and freelance journalist.

blog_post.title: Florida’s Per-Capita COVID-19 Cases Just Surpassed New York’s, but Are the Two Outbreaks Comparable? Yes and No.

lede.lede: Florida has reported over 461,000 total COVID-19 cases, surpassing New York for the highest per-capita caseload in the United States—but a simple comparison doesn’t represent the critical differences in the data we have for the two outbreaks.

blog_post.title: Record New Cases, Surging Hospitalizations, Rising Deaths: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 9

blog_post.title: A New Surge Has Arrived in Michigan, but We Don’t Know What It Will Look Like

lede.lede: According to federal data, COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations have reversed their decline in Michigan, marking a new surge concentrated in and around Detroit, but affecting regions statewide.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Releasing our Annotations on COVID-19 State Data Definitions

lede.lede: As part of our wind-down process, we’re publicly sharing our structured metadata on state COVID-19 data definitions.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Rebecca Glassman has a Master’s in Public Health and is a public health researcher in academia. Opinions expressed are her own.
Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: What We've Learned About the HHS’s Hospitalization Data

lede.lede: Despite a rocky beginning, the current hospitalization and new admissions metrics from the HHS Protect public dataset have stabilized—and they’re now largely harmonious with state-reported hospitalization metrics if we account for differences in data definitions and reporting lag time.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Where to Find Simple COVID-19 Data for the US

lede.lede: As The COVID Tracking Project approaches its final day of data compilation on March 7, 2021, we are recommending a selection of federal data sources to people who want a quick and easy way to keep an eye on the pandemic.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Joseph Bensimon is a member of the COVID Tracking Project’s Data Quality team.
Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Death Numbers

lede.lede: The CDC provides two different datasets regarding COVID-19 fatalities. Here’s a walkthrough of how they compare to each other and to The COVID Tracking Project’s data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Hannah Hoffman is a data entry and data quality shift lead at The COVID Tracking Project and a student in the Washington, DC area.

blog_post.title: How Day-of-Week Effects Impact COVID-19 Data

lede.lede: An understanding of state reporting schedules and day-of-week effects can help explain the reasons that numbers fluctuate from day to day, and what those changes mean.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Nicki Camberg is a student journalist studying Political Science and Statistics at Barnard College, and the City Data Manager at CTP.
Artis Curiskis is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.
Kara Oehler is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.
Judith Oppenheim works on Texas City Data and state outreach at The COVID Tracking Project.

Catherine Pollack is a third year PhD candidate in the Quantitative Biomedical Sciences program at Dartmouth College. Her dissertation research combines data science, epidemiology, and public policy to combat online health misinformation.
Aarushi Sahejpal is a Shift Lead on Long-Term Care and City Data at the COVID Tracking Project. She also studies International Relations & Data Science at American University

Sharon Wang is a volunteer on the COVID Tracking Project and has supported data collection, process design and other various needs. Sharon is also the CEO and Founder of Pragmatic Strategy Co, a boutique consulting firm helping organizations create longevity in their business through operational and leadership effectiveness.

blog_post.title: Introducing the COVID Tracking Project City Dataset

lede.lede: Our new data collection tracks the spread of COVID-19 in 65 cities and counties across the United States, and it lets us see how fatality rates vary widely across geographies.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Amanda French, Community Lead and Data Entry Shift Lead at The COVID Tracking Project, has a doctorate in English and is an expert in digital humanities.
Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.

blog_post.title: The “Good” Metric Is Pretty Bad: Why It’s Hard to Count the People Who Have Recovered from COVID-19

lede.lede: We don’t know how many people in the US have really recovered from COVID-19.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Visualizing COVID-19’s Impact on Hospitals Across the Country

lede.lede: The HHS released a facility-level data set on COVID-19 hospitalizations in December. We’ve taken that data and created an interactive map, allowing the public to see how their local hospitals are faring against this virus.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: All Eyes on Hospitalizations: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Dec 30

lede.lede: Holiday reporting has garbled most metrics. Going by current COVID-19 hospitalizations, outbreaks in the Midwest are still easing, but every other region is in trouble.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Hannah Hoffman is a data entry and data quality shift lead at The COVID Tracking Project and a student in the Washington, DC area.

blog_post.title: How We Source Our Data and Why It Matters

lede.lede: States provide COVID-19 data in a variety of sources and formats. To ensure our data is as accurate and consistent as possible, we spend a lot of time looking at these sources to make sure that we’re capturing the most data possible for each state, while maintaining high standards of data quality and integrity. Today, we’re publicly releasing a detailed set of notes on the sources of all our data points.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Catherine Pollack is a third year PhD candidate in the Quantitative Biomedical Sciences program at Dartmouth College. Her dissertation research combines data science, epidemiology, and public policy to combat online health misinformation.
Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Current, New, and Cumulative Hospitalizations: What They Are and Why They Matter

lede.lede: COVID-19 hospitalizations continue to rise across the country, but the method in which they are reported can take several different forms. We dive into the meaning of some of the most common metrics and comment on why some may be more interpretable than others.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Rebecca Glassman has a Master’s in Public Health and is a public health researcher in academia. Opinions expressed are her own.
Betsy Ladyzhets is a Research Editor at Stacker and works on data quality and the COVID Racial Data Tracker at the COVID Tracking Project.

Catherine Pollack is a third year PhD candidate in the Quantitative Biomedical Sciences program at Dartmouth College. Her dissertation research combines data science, epidemiology, and public policy to combat online health misinformation.

blog_post.title: New HHS dataset tells us precisely where COVID-19 is hitting hospitals

lede.lede: The Department of Health and Human Services released a new public dataset on December 7 that includes data down to the facility level on where COVID-19 patients are hospitalized and how healthcare systems are coping. We explored how to use this dataset and what patterns it can reveal.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Cases Matter

lede.lede: As COVID-19 cases rise across the United States, claims are circulating that case increases are (mostly or entirely) due to expanded testing, and do not indicate a spike in infections. The data does not support this conclusion.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.
Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.
Joseph Bensimon is a member of the COVID Tracking Project’s Data Quality team.

blog_post.title: As North Dakota’s Deaths Metrics Diverge, We’re Switching to a Less Backlogged Measure of Fatalities

lede.lede: North Dakota's growing backlog of death certificates means its count of individuals who died due to COVID is no longer an accurate measure of deaths in the state. As a result, we're switching our metric to deaths among cases, matching the state’s most prominent method of reporting.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Daily COVID-19 Data Is About to Get Weird

lede.lede: The upcoming holiday means that many COVID-19 metrics are going to drop—and then rise—in ways that may trip up unsuspecting observers. Here’s what to watch out for.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.
Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: COVID-19 Hospitalizations Have Hit an All-Time High

lede.lede: More people are now in the hospital with COVID-19 than ever before, and the per-capita hospitalization rates in the Midwest have now surpassed those of the South in the summer’s Sunbelt surge. Hospitals across the country are warning of staff and PPE shortages, and case rates continue to spike in every US region.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: COVID-19 Deaths Are Rising, But Fatality Rates Have Improved

lede.lede: As COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations once again rise across the United States so, inevitably, will deaths. But there is reason to hope that we will not see the devastating fatality rates of the initial spring surge.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.
Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Confirmed and Probable COVID-19 Deaths, Counted Two Ways

lede.lede: We're up to 24 states publishing both confirmed and probable COVID-19 deaths, and we're adding those data points into our API. But states are also using two different ways of deciding which deaths to count as COVID-19 deaths.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Is There a Right Way to Chart COVID-19 Deaths Over Time?

lede.lede: States across the US use two primary methods for announcing COVID-19 deaths: date of death (reported) and date of death (actual). To analyze how the pandemic is trending across the country, understanding the relationship between these two data points is crucial. Here's what we've learned from investigating both methods in three of our largest hotspots: Arizona, Florida, and Texas.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Sara Simon works on The COVID Tracking Project’s data quality team and is also a contributing writer. She most recently worked as an investigative data reporter at Spotlight PA and software engineer at The New York Times.

blog_post.title: Why The COVID Tracking Project’s Death Count Hasn’t Hit 200,000

lede.lede: Several sites tracking the progression of the virus hit a grim milestone today: more than 200,000 deaths since the pandemic began. Our figures haven’t yet reached that level. Here’s why.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Testing In Limbo, Hospitalizations and Deaths Still Dropping: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 10

lede.lede: A long holiday weekend makes ambiguous testing data even harder to understand, but hospitalizations are dropping, which is good.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Joanna Pearlstein is an editorial lead at the Covid Tracking Project and a former editor at WIRED and Protocol.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Holiday Reporting Lags Interrupt Positive Trends: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 17

lede.lede: Though cases are rising in parts of the Midwest, hospitalizations in the West and South continued trending downward. The Labor Day holiday impacted data reporting lag times both this week and last, obscuring what had been positive trends in September.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Finally, Some Good News. This Week in COVID-19 Data, Aug 20

lede.lede: Key data points in our COVID-19 tracking are finally beginning to trend positively. In the South, tests rose while cases fell, a pattern not seen there since early spring. Hospitalizations fell for the third week straight, but deaths remained above 1,000 a day on average.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Rebecca Glassman has a Master’s in Public Health and is a public health researcher in academia. Opinions expressed are her own.
Betsy Ladyzhets is a Research Editor at Stacker and works on data quality and the COVID Racial Data Tracker at the COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Hospitalization Data Reported by the HHS vs. the States: Jumps, Drops, and Other Unexplained Phenomena

lede.lede: In mid-July the federal government began requiring hospitals to report COVID-19 data to the HHS rather than to the CDC. We compared current hospitalization data reported by the federal government and state health departments since the switch, and found contradictions that suggest the federal data continue to be unreliable, while the state datasets face their own challenges.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Robinson Meyer is a co-founder of The COVID Tracking Project and a staff writer at The Atlantic.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: What’s Going on with COVID-19 Hospitalization Data?

lede.lede: Data for current COVID-19 hospitalizations in the United States—one of our most valuable metrics for understanding the pandemic and its effects—has become highly erratic in recent weeks. Here's what we've learned from watching the data closely, and from our initial analysis of the hospitalization data being published by the federal government.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Alice Goldfarb leads The COVID Tracking Project’s part in The COVID Racial Data Tracker, and is a Nieman Visiting Fellow.

blog_post.title: Record New Cases, Surging Hospitalizations, Rising Deaths: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 9

lede.lede: The South continues to be the epicenter of surges in both cases and hospitalizations. In Arizona, Florida, South Carolina, and Texas, COVID-19 deaths have begun to climb following jumps in new cases. And for the first time since April, deaths are rising nationally.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Whet Moser is a freelance writer in Chicago.
Conor Kelly is the director of data analytics at Hanover Research.

blog_post.title: To Understand the US Pandemic, We Need Hospitalization Data—and We Almost Have It

lede.lede: Hospitalization data can help us understand the severity of COVID-19 outbreaks in the United States, and even see a little bit of what's to come. Until very recently, we didn't have a national summary figure—now we can finally piece together a national statistic from states that provide it, and estimate the rest.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Whet Moser is a freelance writer in Chicago.

blog_post.title: Why Changing COVID-19 Demographics in the US Make Death Trends Harder to Understand

lede.lede: COVID-19 death data lags behind testing data in ways we mostly understand. What we only partly understand is how an infection rate that seems to be skewing younger will affect the death toll in surging regional outbreaks.

","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"This kept us focused on making sure we understood the data and the conclusions we could draw from them, especially as the pandemic evolved.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-2","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The Data Landscape","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"As March 2020 progressed, some states launched COVID-19 data dashboards; others reported data in press conferences—or not at all. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"It quickly became apparent that","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"daily, close contact with the data was necessary to understand what states were reporting.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Madrigal told CNN’s Brian Stelter","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://edition.cnn.com/audio/podcasts/reliable-sources?episodeguid=984361a0-6e46-4f09-9508-ace20141b230"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" “At first, we just thought you could pull numbers off dashboards and that was going to be the main process. As it turned out, we actually needed to do deep research.”","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Throughout the pandemic, COVID-19 testing and outcomes data have been ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"a messy patchwork","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/analysis-updates/three-covid-19-data-problems"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"States frequently changed how, what, and where they reported data.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" In the absence of clear federal guidelines, states were largely left to figure out how to publish data without help. Our core data entry team ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"developed extensive processes","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/analysis-updates/how-we-entered-covid-19-testing-outcomes-data"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" to deal with this patchworked state reporting.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"When we started the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"COVID Racial Data Tracker (CRDT)","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/race"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", fewer than one fifth of US states reported race and ethnicity testing and outcomes data. As of March 7, 2021, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"51 jurisdictions report race and ethnicity data","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/race/dashboard"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" for cases and for deaths. The quantity of data increased over the pandemic, but ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"states continued to struggle with quality","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/analysis-updates/state-of-COVID-race-and-ethnicity-data"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":".","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"While the frustrations of state COVID-19 data reporting were obvious to all of our data entry teams, the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Long-Term-Care COVID Tracker (LTC)","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/nursing-homes-long-term-care-facilities"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" team dealt with particularly agonizing discrepancies in long-term-care data—especially at the facility level. Without clear reporting standards, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"state long-term-care data is shocking in its deficiencies","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/analysis-updates/what-we-know-about-the-impact-of-the-pandemic-on-our-most-vulnerable-community"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"States that reported data publicly often did so in wildly different ways, rendering comparisons across states exceptionally challenging.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The COVID-19 data that we collected—testing and outcomes, race and ethnicity, and long-term care—were largely unstandardized and fragmented. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Had we set up a fully automated data capture system in March 2020, it would have failed within days.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-2","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"What We Automated","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Over the course of our data collection, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"we aimed to build increasingly strong automated tooling to validate and augment our manual work.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Zach Lipton, Data Infrastructure Co-lead, worked initially on ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"urlwatch","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://github.com/COVID19Tracking/covid-tracking"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", a first step towards automation, with the goal of alerting volunteers when data on state pages and dashboards changed. Even reaching that relatively modest goal proved to be a huge undertaking: ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"early on, there were often days when as many as ten states made major changes to their sites or rolled out new dashboards.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" Due to this whirlwind pace of updates and reporting changes, tracking states that published structured, machine-readable data was challenging and time-consuming. Dealing with states that used dashboard platforms like Tableau or Power BI, or which published their data through images on Facebook, proved deeply frustrating.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"A core tenet of The COVID Tracking Project is data transparency. To show our work, Julia Kodysh, our Data Infrastructure Co-Lead, built an ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"automated screenshots system","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/analysis-updates/how-why-covid-tracking-project-built-screenshot-system"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" that captured snapshots of state COVID-19 dashboards and pages. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"We configured hundreds of screenshots and eventually reached 100% coverage of our 797 core testing and outcomes data points.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" Screenshots were invaluable in building trust in our data; ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"we amassed a trove of screenshots in our ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"public archive","marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://screenshots.covidtracking.com"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" that allowed us—and our data users—to verify our data","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" with an easily accessible series of state COVID-19 data page snapshots.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Rebma, an infrastructure engineer, built an ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"automated data fetcher","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://github.com/COVID19Tracking/covid19-datafetcher"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" that served to verify the testing and outcomes data that our volunteers entered during data entry shifts. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"This automated checking was tremendously helpful for the volunteers who entered and double-checked roughly 800 data points every day.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Carol Brandmaier-Monahan and Pat Kelly maintained a similar data fetcher system for CRDT race and ethnicity data that would pull the often-messy numbers into our entry spreadsheets for humans to validate. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"The system saved volunteers hours of entering data and allowed them to focus on its correctness.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Despite the hurdles of long-term-care data, Lipton was able to automate some tools to facilitate LTC data collection: ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"facility-level data scrapers","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://github.com/COVID19Tracking/covid-tracking-data/tree/master/data-collection-scripts/ltc-scrapers"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" for Nevada and West Virginia’s Power BI dashboards, for Kansas’ Tableau dashboard, and for Utah’s ArcGIS dashboard. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Before these scrapers, collecting data took the LTC team hours for each of these states.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" Additionally, Kodysh led our Data Infrastructure team in building an extensive ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"data processing API","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://github.com/COVID19Tracking/ltc-data-processing"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" for long-term-care data ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"to address deficiencies in state reporting","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", like calculating true cumulative case and death counts in Kentucky to correct for a data reset that saw all facilities drop down to zero reported cases and deaths at the beginning of 2021.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Automation helped immensely to ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"capture constantly changing data like time series","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/analysis-updates/how-we-used-multiple-dating-schemes-to-provide-the-most-complete-picture-of-the-pandemic"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". States often revised and updated time series as lagged data entered the reporting pipelines; for example, a state’s testing number for a particular day might be revised once additional tests from that day were reported to the state health department. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Using scripts to fetch time series data daily, we were able to maintain an updated picture of this ever-changing data that we used for checks and research.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We automated more as the pandemic went on and as state data became more stable, but ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"we never fully automated any data point in our testing and outcomes, CRDT, or LTC datasets.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-2","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The Benefits of Human Involvement","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Not automating has an obvious cost—human labor.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" We estimate that our volunteers spent more than 20,000 hours doing data entry alone. But there were clear benefits, some of which weren't easy to foresee as we built out processes at the beginning of the project.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Seeking out and manually entering each data point gave us a detailed understanding of the data that we would not have been able to develop had we automated data collection. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"We knew when new data points were added and came across caveats and notes posted on state data pages. When metrics changed abruptly, we sought out explanations that states sometimes posted to explain issues like data dumps and reporting lag. The perils of failing to do so are evident: for example, on March 18, 2021, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"CNN reported dramatic COVID-19 case spikes","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/18/us/michigan-covid-19-cases-increase/index.html"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" in Alabama and Delaware, citing data that had been collected automatically—and missing notes that both states published on their dashboards clarifying that the increases resulted from backlogged cases. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Additionally, we learned what was normal and what was abnormal on a state by state basis, enabling us to make informed decisions when handling reporting anomalies.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Another benefit: ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"human eyes on—and heavy use of—data pages and dashboards enabled us to give informed feedback to states, ranging from comments about website accessibility to requesting that states publish more data to correcting errors. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"For example, on November 5, 2020, Hawaii was incorrectly summing numbers after a transition to a newer data processing method—reporting 16,096 cumulative hospitalizations on one dashboard and 1,125 on another. We noticed the discrepancy between the two dashboards and submitted feedback to a contact at the state Emergency Management Agency, after which Hawaii corrected the mistake—1,125 was the correct total—and explained what had happened.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Visiting state data pages each day meant that ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"we discovered new metrics soon after they were first posted.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" Had we relied on scripts to pull data, we would have taken much longer to discover newly reported data.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"A project like ours requires experience in journalism, computing, reporting, and science communication, to name but a few disciplines. More basically, though, we needed huge numbers of volunteers with some familiarity with spreadsheets to enter data. As such, we ended up recruiting hundreds of volunteers into data entry. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Working data entry shifts allowed our volunteers a taste of the work and of our unique culture, offering an excellent introduction to the varied opportunities to contribute within the project. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"After starting in data entry, many volunteers moved on to roles in editorial, research, data science, and other teams.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Manual data entry provided a ritual for volunteers. We collected long-term-care data weekly and race and ethnicity data twice weekly. And","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" day after day, through weekends, holidays, and losses both personal and global, we collected testing and outcomes data for 56 jurisdictions.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" Our data entry teams formed the core of our community: ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"data collection is rote work, but when done as part of a supportive group, it can offer a sense of purpose and community.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-2","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"What We Learned","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The COVID Tracking Project operated in a data landscape without consistent reporting standards. We worked with constantly changing dashboards, dashboards designed to be hard to scrape automatically, and even changing data definitions. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Building automated tooling facilitated our manual data collection and was crucial to our ability to verify data. Ultimately, though, human scrutiny was needed to develop a deep understanding of the data.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" Perhaps most importantly, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"collecting data manually allowed us to build a culture of curiosity and care about the data","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" in a way that we could not have done if we were a primarily automated project.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Additional contributions from Julia Kodysh, Michal Mart, and Theo Michel.","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

lede.lede: Looking back on a year of collecting COVID-19 data, here’s a summary of the tools we automated to make our data entry smoother and why we ultimately relied on manual data collection.
